conclusion: To find the electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square, we need to consider the electric field due to each charge and how they interact at the point of intersection.
The electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r from the charge is given by E = kq/r^2, where k is the Coulomb constant.
The electric field due to the charge at A (+q) is E = kq/r^2.
The electric field due to the charge at B (+q) is E = kq/r^2.
The electric field due to the charge at C (-q) is E = k(-q)/r^2.
The electric field due to the charge at D (-q) is E = k(-q)/r^2.
The electric field at the intersection of the diagonals of the square is the vector sum of the electric fields due to each charge.
The electric field at the intersection is given by E_intersection = kq/r^2 + k(-q)/r^2 = k(-q + q)/r^2 = k(-q)/r^2.
The electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square is k(-q)/r^2.
